reward.name: Blessing of Plumage
entries: {@i Level 1–4}
A creature you touch grows golden feathers as if you cast the {@spell plumage armor|Honkonomicon}* spell. Once you do so, you can't do it again until the next dawn.

reward.name: Blessing of the Avian Sight
entries: {@i Level 11–16}
As an action, you channel the enigmatic gaze of the Goose as if you casted the {@spell gaze of the golden goose|Honkonomicon}* spell. Once you do so, you can't do it again until the next dawn.

reward.name: Blessing of the Golden Quill
entries: {@i Level 17–20}
You own a feather of the Great Golden Goose herself, that you can use as if it was the {@spell power word quill|Honkonomicon}* spell. Once you do so, the feather loses all power.

reward.name: Blessing of the Guardian Goose
entries: {@i Level 5–10}

A celestial gander is assigned to look over you, and you can summon it as an action as if it was the {@spell summon goose guardian|Honkonomicon}* spell (Honking Defender only). Once you do so, you can't do it again until the next dawn.

reward.name: Charm of the Honkeous Laughter
entries: {@i Level 1–4}
This charm allows you to cast the {@spell honkeous laughter|Honkonomicon}* spell as an action, no components required. Once used three times, the charm goes away.

reward.name: Charm of the Honktropy
entries: {@i Level 11–16}
This charm allows you to cast the {@spell prismatic spray}* spell as an action, no components required. Once used three times, the charm goes away.

reward.name: Charm of the Primordial Havonk
entries: {@i Level 17–20}

You own a goose figurine made of the same materials that the Ur-goose is made of, that you can break to activate the {@spell call of the Ur-goose|Honkonomicon}* spell. Once you do so, the figurine loses its power.

reward.name: Charm of the Wild Goose Chase
entries: {@i Level 5–10}

One pair of boots or shoes in your possession becomes a pair of {@item wild goose chasers|Honkonomicon}* (DM's choice) for the next 10 days. The charm then vanishes from you and the items go back to normal.

reward.name: Curse of the Golden Feathers
entries: This is similar to the curse that falls on anybody that touches a {@creature goose of the golden feathers|Honkonomicon}, punishing the greed of whoever wants to pick the goose's golden feathers.

entries.name: Pronouncement
entries: When Mother Goose recounts the fable of the goose of the golden feathers, she says "Who wishes to pluck a feather of the golden goose, will find the feather to be as sticky as its desires."

entries.name: Burden
entries: The target that touched the protected item or creature becomes {@condition restrained}. While {@condition restrained}, the target is stuck to the item or creature and will follow it wherever it goes, unless one of them is teleported away. Another creature touching or hitting with a melee attack the cursed target is also targeted by this curse, becoming stuck to the touched creature instead.

entries.name: Resolution
entries: The curse lasts until the cursed target makes a gesture of genuine generosity, like giving away its precious belongings at least as worth as the average value of a magic item for the character's level or the creature's CR (see {@book Magic Items in the Dungeon Master's Guide|DMG|7|Magic Items}). Separating with teleportation the target and the touched object or creature also breaks the curse.

reward.name: Feathered Doom
entries: One of Anserath's favorite tricks, it turns the creature into an archenemy of all goosekind.

entries.name: Pronouncement
entries: The creature hears a threatening, otherworldly honk that is full of hate.

entries.name: Burden
entries: Every goose creature with Intelligence 3 or lower is hostile to the cursed creature and attacks it on sight. Other goose creatures make a {@dc 12} Wisdom saving, becoming hostile to the cursed creature on a failed save.

entries.name: Resolution
entries: The target must become part of a flock of goose creatures for a full, uninterrupted week. If the target approaches the flock with this intention in mind, then a {@dc 20} Wisdom ({@skill Animal Handling}) check is enough to prevent the geese from attacking it (unless the geese have other reasons to attack). During the week, the target must spend at least 8 hours per day in the company of its flock, behaving just like them. After doing so, the curse is lifted.

reward.name: Killing the Golden Goose
entries: Killing a creature protected by this curse is a sure way to lose one's wealth.

entries.name: Pronouncement
entries: The fabled goose of the golden eggs provides one golden egg per day. Who kills it, usually in hope to harvest more golden eggs from the goose's dead body, brings down this curse on itself. From this comes the idiom "killing the goose of the golden eggs", known to many.

entries.name: Burden
entries: The target has disadvantage on any ability check to find precious goods or accumulate wealth of any kind. Whenever one or more dice are rolled to randomly determine the amount or the value of treasures or items found by the character, the result is always the one less convenient for the target (like the lowest amount of coins, or the highest price for a magic item).

entries.name: Resolution
entries: The protected creature that was killed must be brought back to life, or the target must find an egg from a golden goose, hatch it, protect it and nurture it personally until it becomes adult. This usually takes six months.

reward.name: Uncanny Goose
entries: The creature crossed the geese of power and now is being stalked by a magical, unkillable goose.

entries.name: Pronouncement
entries: This curse is usually signaled by a goose-shaped birthmark on the body of the target. Depending on the effect intended by the cursing power, killing such a creature can transmit the curse to the killer

entries.name: Burden
entries: Whenever the target rolls a 1 on the {@dice d20} for an ability check, attack roll or saving throw, a {@creature domestic goose|Honkonomicon} uncannily appears in a free space within 20 feet of the target. The goose is immune to all divination and mind-reading magical effects, and any kind of magic effectively registers that the goose is not there (but it is). The goose can be killed or imprisoned, but comes back to life at full hit points or frees itself as soon as nobody is watching it.

entries.name: Resolution
entries: The target must be transformed into a beast that is a goose creature, then receive the {@spell remove curse} spell or similar magic.

reward.name: Webbed feet
entries: A territory that is sacred to geese will curse the feet of who walks through it.

entries.name: Pronouncement
entries: By the entrance of the area, a writing in {@language Abyssal}, {@language Celestial} or {@language Primordial} says: "Who dares to step in the land of geese, will only take goose steps."

entries.name: Burden
entries: The targets receives the legs effect of the {@spell web limbs|Honkonomicon}* spell.

entries.name: Resolution
entries: The target has to befriend a goose creature.

reward.name: Woeful Honking
entries: The character seriously disrespected a goose creature or goosekind in general, and will now suffer the consequences by sounding just like the thing that the character offended.

entries.name: Pronouncement
entries: The curse can be pronounced by a powerful goose creature or spellcaster, or just be part of the folklore and rituals revolving around geese. The curse usually recites: "Whoever will speak ill of the goose, will then speak just as the goose".

entries.name: Burden
entries: When the target first receives the curse, and when the target rolls a 1 on the {@dice d20} for an ability check, attack roll or saving throw, it can express itself only through honking for 10 minutes (therefore can't cast spells with verbal components or use magic items that require an activation word). Roll a {@dice d20} every 10 minutes: on a result from 11 to 20, the target's speech ability goes back to normal.

entries.name: Resolution
entries: The target must create, commission or find a work of art that shows the beauty, power or good qualities of geese, and donate it to a place dedicated to them (like a temple of the Great Golden Goose.)

reward.name: Wrath of the Goose
entries: The mind of the character is shattered by fowlish thoughts, becoming confused and dangerous. This curse usually originates from Anserath, the Honking Chaos.

entries.name: Pronouncement
entries: By the protected area, object or creature, it is possible to hear several chaotic honks that come from nowhere but can be heard directly in the mind.

entries.name: Burden
entries: When the target rolls a 1 on the {@dice d20} for an ability check, attack roll or saving throw, it receives the effects of the {@spell honkeous laughter|Honkonomicon}* spell. If this happens again while the target is under the effect of this spell, the target uses its reaction to move towards the closest non-goose creature and make a melee attack against it.

entries.name: Resolution
entries: The target must find the transcendent peace of the Great Golden Goose. This can be achieved by going through a migration of enlightenment (a quest at the DM's choice), touching the {@item Golden Egg of Divinity|Honkonomicon}, or receiving a {@spell remove curse} spell from a goose creature that considers the target worthy of it.

images.title: The fabled curse of the golden feathers at work

spell.name: Call of the Ur-Goose

m.text: 5000 gp worth of ambers which the spell consumes and the figurine of a goose carved in wood of a tree at least 500 years old worth at least 100 gp

entries: You summon the terrifying presence of the {@creature Ur-Goose|Honkonomicon}, which appears in an unoccupied space within 60 feet and stays until the spell ends.
You have no control on the {@creature Ur-Goose|Honkonomicon}, and it's hostile to all creatures.

Being weakened by the ordeal, the {@creature Ur-Goose|Honkonomicon} has no legendary actions available during the first {@dice 1d4} rounds, but can use an action to perform one of its legendary actions. After those rounds have passed, the {@creature Ur-Goose|Honkonomicon} gains 3 legendary actions and can use an action to end the spell and return to its native plane

After {@dice 1d4} rounds, the {@creature Ur-Goose|Honkonomicon} can use an action to end the spell and return to where it came from, or you can end the spell as an action while {@status concentration||concentrating} and banish the {@creature Ur-Goose|Honkonomicon} into where it was before being summoned. Otherwise,this spell will last after its duration, won't be dispelled by any means and won't end, and the {@creature Ur-Goose|Honkonomicon} won't unwillingly leave by any means but a {@spell wish} spell unless the wooden goose figurine is destroyed.

spell.name: Chaos Honk
entries: You project with your voice the powerful honk of Anserath, the Honking Chaos, in a 60-foot cone in front of you. Each object in the area takes {@damage 6d8} thunder damage. Creatures in the area must make a Constitution saving throw or take the same damage and roll {@dice 1d10} to determine an additional random effect:

items: 1–2: falls {@condition prone}, drops anything it's holding and is {@condition unconscious} until the end of its next turn. Creatures that can't be put to sleep by magic are immune to this effect.
3–6: falls {@condition prone} and can express only honking (therefore i.e. can't talk and can't use its voice to provide verbal components or spell activation words) until the end of its next turn.
7: grows a blue beard and mustaches made of plumes that disappear in 1 week.
8: grows a purple tail made of plumes that disappears in 1 week.
9: grows a red crest made of plumes that disappears in 1 week.
10: no additional effect.

entries: For each die scoring a 1 in this spell's damage roll, targets roll an additional time on this table, but can't be subject to the same effect twice.
A creature that succeeds in the saving throw takes only half as much damage and no other effect.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels:
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 5th level or higher, it deals an additional {@damage 1d8} thunder damage and targets take an additional random effect for each slot level above 4th.

spell.name: Conjure Honkland Beings
entries: You summon goose creatures that appear in an unoccupied space that you can see within range. Choose one of the following options for what appears:

items: One goose creature of CR 2 or lower
Two goose creatures of CR 1 or lower
Four goose creatures of CR 1/2 or lower
Eight goose creatures of CR 1/4 or lower

entries: A summoned creature disappears when it drops to 0 hit points or when the spell ends.

The summoned creatures are friendly to you and your companions. Roll initiative for the summoned creatures as a group, which have their own turns. They obey any verbal commands that you issue to them (no action required by you). If you don't issue any commands to them, they defend themselves from hostile creatures, but otherwise take no actions.
The DM has the creatures' statistics.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels:
entries: When you cast this spell using certain higher-level spell slots, you choose one of the summoning options above, and more creatures appear: twice as many with a 6th-level slot and three times as many with an 8th-level slot.

spell.name: Find Giant Goose Steed
entries: You summon a spirit that assumes the form of an unusually intelligent, strong and loyal steed, creating a long-lasting bond with the creature. The steed has the statistic of a {@creature giant goose|Honkonomicon}, though it is a celestial (bound to the Great Golden Goose), fiend (bound to Anserath, the Goose of Chaos) or an elemental (bound to the Ur-Goose) at your choice instead of a beast. Additionally, the steed has an intelligence of 6 and gains the ability to understand one of your languages.

Your steed serves you as a mount, both in combat and out, and you have an instinctive bond with it that allows you to fight as a seamless unit. If you wish so, any spell you cast that targets only you while mounted on your steed also targets the summoned creature.

Furthermore, while mounted on your steed whenever you roll a 1 or a 20 on the {@dice d20} your goose steed enters a status of confused frenzy until the end of your next turn. While frenzied, the goose steed can't be controlled as a mount but instead takes its turn on its own initiative. During its turn, roll {@dice 1d10}:

items: 1: The goose mount uses its action to make an attempt to force you to dismount. You must make a contested Strength ({@skill Athletics}) ability check against it or fall {@condition prone} in an adjacent space.
2–6: The goose mount doesn't move or take actions this turn.
7–8: The goose mount moves toward the nearest creature (but you) and uses its action to make a melee attack against it.
9–10: The goose mount acts normally but on its own.

entries: When the steed drops to 0 hit points, it disappears, leaving behind no physical form. You can also dismiss your steed at any time as an action, causing it to disappear. In either case, casting this spell again summons the same steed, restored to its hit point maximum. While your steed is within 1 mile of you, you can communicate with each other telepathically. You can't have more than one steed bonded by this spell at a time. As an action, you can release the steed from its bond at any time, causing it to disappear

spell.name: Gander's Blow
entries: A thick and hard gander beak grows instead of your mouth (if any). When you take the {@action Attack} action while this spell is active, you can make an extra unarmed strike with the beak as a part of that action. This attack can be used for a {@action grapple} attempt and the beak counts as a free hand for that purpose.
While this spell is active, you can communicate only by honking (therefore you can't talk and can't use your voice to provide verbal components or spell activation words).

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels:
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 3rd level or higher, the extra attack deals {@damage 1d6} additional bludgeoning damage on a hit for each spell slot level above 2nd. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, your neck grows longer and your gander beak attack has a range of 5 feet more for each spell slot level above 3rd.

spell.name: Gaze of the Golden Goose
entries: For the spell's duration, your eyes become a golden honky void imbued with goose power. One creature of your choice that you can see within range gains one of the following effects. On each of your turns until the spell ends, you can use your action to target another creature with this spell. The same creature can't benefit from more than one effect at time.

entries.name: Happy Honkness
entries: The target gains 10 temporary hit points at the start of each of its turns until the spell ends.

entries.name: Feather Fury
entries: The target gains advantage to attack rolls until the spell ends.

entries.name: Goosey Glibness
entries: The target doubles its speed and doesn't provoke {@action opportunity attack||attacks of opportunity} until the spell ends.

spell.name: Gooseance

time.condition: which you take when you or any other creature within range fails an attack roll, ability check or saving throw

entries: You sternly honk at failure. A willing creature you can see targeted by this spell adds {@dice 1d4} to the failing roll that triggered the reaction, potentially turning it into a success.

Whether this happens or not, for the next minute you and that creature can't express anything except by honking (therefore i.e. can't talk and can't use its voice to provide verbal components or spell activation words).

spell.name: Goosefeather Fall

time.condition: which you take when you fall

entries: As you fall, you wave the feather in the direction of a creature within range, which is forced to make a Strength saving throw or be pulled up to 10 feet toward you and fall with you (this can cause you or the target to end your turn in the same space).

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels:
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 3rd level or higher, you can target one additional creature for each slot level above 2nd.

spell.name: Honkeous Laughter
entries: A creature of your choice that you can see within range must succeed a Wisdom saving throw or be {@condition frightened} by geese. While {@condition frightened} in this way, the target finds every non-goose creature ridiculous and funny and upon seeing any of them is compelled to burst in a loud honk at the start of each of its turn, being audible within 300 feet and dealing {@damage 1d6} thunder damage to any non-goose creature within 5 feet from it.
At the end of each of its turns, if the target can't see any creature, it can repeat the saving throw. On a success, the spell ends.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels:
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, you can target one additional creature for each slot level above 1st. The creatures must be within 30 feet of each other when you target them.

spell.name: Plumage Armor
entries: A thick, soft and shiny goose plumage grows on the target, covering most of its skin. The target gains 5 temporary hit points; while having these hit points it has resistance to fire and cold damage and ignores any negative effect for fighting underwater.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, you can target one additional creature for each slot level above 1st.

spell.name: Power Word Quill
entries: You utter the secret name of the Sacred Quill of Power, which pops in your hand. Any creature can use it in any of the following ways, then the spell ends.

entries.name: Tickle to Death
entries: You tickle a creature within 5 feet of you with the Sacred Quill of Power. To do so you must use your action to make a melee spell attack against the creature. On a hit the target falls {@condition prone} and is {@condition incapacitated} laughing while you {@status concentration||concentrate} on this spell and stay within 5 feet of the target. At the end of your next turn, if the effect is still on, the target dies and the spell ends. If the target has legendary action, it takes {@damage 10d10} psychic damage instead of dying.

entries.name: Write the Honkswer
entries: You pose a question to the Sacred Quill of Power, which instantly writes the true answer to that question (if any) on the nearest flat surface, then the spell ends. The Quill will answer in any possible moment to the first question made by the creature holding it, no matter if meant to be "the" question. The answer will be true, but not necessarily complete or useful.

This unique magical and legendary plume is exactly the same as a normal quill, except for the powers above. It can be normally destroyed or seized by force from its possessor with a successful contested Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check.

When the spell ends, the Sacred Quill of Power turns into a normal quill. Each time you cast this spell again before a year has passed since last time there is a cumulative {@chance 10} chance to summon a normal quill instead of the Sacred Quill of Power.

entries.name: Variant: Power Word Quill and Legendary Creatures
entries: The power word quill spell can't instantly kill creatures with legendary actions but deals them a great amount of damage instead. This is similar to how a {@item vorpal sword||vorpal weapon} works against a legendary creature.

If you are playing a campaign with a more gritty or realistic style where each and every creature can die a sudden death, you can decide to ignore this rule and let power word quill instantly kill even a legendary creature. As a DM, be aware that this change could enable the characters to kill without a saving throw even extremely powerful creatures, like the {@creature tarrasque} or an ancient dragon.

spell.name: Quill the Dead
entries: A tiny illusory quill moved by a skeletal hand appears near a creature you can see within range, and mimicking your moves gently tickles the target forcing it to make an Intelligence saving throw or take {@damage 1d6} psychic damage. A creature failing this save has disadvantage to ability checks and, if able, laughs so loudly that any creature within 100 feet can hear the laughter clearly. A creature without feet or armpits is immune to the effects of this spell.
This spell's damage increases by {@dice 1d6} when you reach 5th level ({@dice 2d6}), 11th level ({@dice 3d6}), and 17th level ({@dice 4d6}).

spell.name: Storm of the Honking Chaos
entries: You call forth the power of Honking Chaos which comes in the form of six 10-foot radius spherical bursts of honking nonsense within range. A creature in the area of more than one burst is affected only once. As a bonus action on each of your subsequent turns, until the spell ends, you can move any number of the bursts by up to 20 feet within the spell's range.
At the end of each of your turns, you choose on of the following effects:

entries.name: Cachonkphony
entries: Loud and senseless honking fills the air in the area and can be heard up to a mile away. Creatures in the area are {@condition deafened} until the end of your next turn and must make a Strength saving throw or take {@damage 3d10} thunder damage. Creatures made of inorganic materials such as stone or crystal have disadvantage to this saving throw. Nonmagical objects in the area that are not worn or carried also take the damage.

entries.name: Flaming Plumes
entries: A fluffy cloud of burning plumes fills the area and creatures in it must make a Dexterity saving throw or take {@damage 3d12} fire damage. Flammable objects that are not worn or carried instantly ignite and the area fills with heavily obscuring smoke that dissipates at the beginning of your next turn.

entries.name: Geeseturbing Madness
entries: Anserath's madness permeates minds within the area. Any creature in the area has disadvantage on Constitution saving throws made to keep their {@status concentration}, and must make a Wisdom saving throw or take {@damage 3d8} psychic damage and be able to express only honking until the end of your next turn.

entries.name: Thonkxic Eggs
entries: Multiple rotten eggs materialize midair and suddenly explode, filling the air with a sulfur-smelling gas. Creatures in the area must make a Constitution saving throw or take {@damage 3d12} poison damage, drop {@condition prone} reeking and be {@condition poisoned} until the end of your next turn.

spell.name: Summon Goose Guardian

m.text: A platinum goose figurine worth at least 500 gp

entries: You call forth a {@creature goose spirit|Honkonomicon}. It manifests in a different corporeal form depending on the Goose of Power it is bound with, and appears in an unoccupied space within range. This corporeal form uses the {@creature Goose Spirit|Honkonomicon} Stat block. When you cast the spell choose between Honking Defender, Chaos Gander or Primal Honker. Your choice determines certain traits in its stat block. The creature disappears when it drops to 0 hit points or when the spell ends. The creature is an ally to you and your companions. In combat, the creature shares your initiative count, but it takes its turn immediately after yours. It obeys your verbal commands (no action required by you). If you don't issue any, it takes the {@action Dodge} action and uses its move to avoid danger.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels:
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 6th level or higher, use the higher level whenever the spell's level appears in the stat block.

spell.name: Swift Quillver

components.m: an empty quiver and a goose feather

entries: You transmute your quiver so it produces an endless supply of goose quill shaped darts, which seems to leap into your hand when you reach for it. These magical quills can be thrown or used as ammunition for any bow, crossbow or {@item blowgun|PHB}, having a range of 100/400 ft and dealing {@damage 1d12} piercing damage regardless of the weapon used.
Upon hitting a foe with any of these quills, once per turn you can channel the magic of a Great Goose of Power on the quill triggering one of these effects:

entries.name: Chaos Quill
entries: The quill deals an additional {@damage 1d8} force damage and a target hit by this quill must use its reaction to move in a random direction up to its speed (this movement can provoke {@action opportunity attack||attacks of opportunity}) as a chaos pulse flows in its body.

entries.name: Golden Quill
entries: The quill deals an additional {@damage 1d8} radiant damage and a target hit by this quill is {@condition blinded} until the end of its next turn as a light flash erupts by the quill.

entries.name: Ur-quill
entries: The quill deals an additional {@damage 1d8} poison damage and a target hit by this quill is {@condition restrained} until the end of its next turn as the quill transmutes in thorns and vines entangling it.

spell.name: Web Limbs
entries: A creature of your choice that you can see within range is forced to make a Constitution saving throw that can willingly fail. A creature failing this saving throw is subject to one of these effects (your choice):

entries.name: Webbed Feet
entries: Target's feet become webbed. The creature gains swimming speed equal to its normal speed (adding it to any swimming speed it already has got) when not wearing footwear, but upon taking the {@action Dash} action it must make a Dexterity ({@skill Acrobatics}) {@dc 10} ability check or fall {@condition prone}. A creature without feet or with already webbed feet is immune to this effect.

entries.name: Webbed Hands
entries: Target's hands become webbed. The creature gains swimming speed equal to its normal speed (adding it to any swimming speed it already has got) but can't wear gloves or rings and has disadvantage to any Dexterity ability check that involves a fine use of fingers, such as pickpocket attempts or using {@item thieves' tools|PHB}. A creature with no hands or with already webbed hands is immune to this effect.
A {@spell remove curse}, {@spell greater restoration} or {@spell heal} spell will revert any of these effects.

item.name: Manual of Feathers Golems
entries: This tome contains information and incantations necessary to make a particular type of golem. The DM chooses the type or determines it randomly. To decipher and use the manual, you must be a spellcaster with at least two 5th-level spell slots. A creature that can't use a manual of golems and attempts to read it takes {@damage 6d6} psychic damage.

To create a {@creature feathers golem|Honkonomicon}, you must spend 20 days, working without interruption with the manual at hand and resting no more than 8 hours per day. You must also pay 25,000 gp to purchase supplies. Once you finish creating the golem, the book is consumed in eldritch flames. The golem becomes animate when the ashes of the manual are sprinkled on it. It is under your control, and it understands and obeys your spoken commands.

monster.name: Goose Spirit

type.note: ; celestial (Honking Defender); fiend (Chaos Gander); elemental (Primal Honker)

ac.special: 11 + the level of the spell (natural armor) + 2 (honking defender only)

languages: understands the languages you speak but can express only through honking

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The spirit makes a number of attacks equal to half this spell's level (rounded down).

action.name: Beak
entries: {@atk mw} {@hitYourSpellAttack} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}{@damage 1d10 + 3 + summonSpellLevel} piercing damage, and the target is {@condition grappled} by the spirit's beak if it's Huge or smaller (escape DC equals {@dcYourSpellSave}).

action.name: Booming Honk (Primal Honker Only)
entries: {@atk rs} {@hitYourSpellAttack} to hit, range 120 ft., one target. {@h}{@damage 1d10 + 3 + summonSpellLevel} thunder damage and any creature within 10 feet of the target must make a Constitution saving throw or take the same damage and fall {@condition prone}.

action.name: Honk of Fury (Chaos Gander Only)
entries: {@atk rw} {@hitYourSpellAttack} to hit, range 120 ft., one target. {@h}{@damage 1d10 + 3 + summonSpellLevel} fire damage and any creature within 5 feet of the target (including the target itself) can use its reaction to make one melee attack.

action.name: Threatening Honk (Honking Defender Only)
entries: {@atk rw} {@hitYourSpellAttack} to hit, range 120 ft., one target. {@h}{@damage 1d10 + 3 + summonSpellLevel} radiant damage and the target makes a successful Wisdom saving throw to not be {@condition frightened} until the end of the spirit's next turn.

ac.special: 11 + the level of the spell (natural armor)
13 + the level of the spell (natural armor)
11 + the level of the spell (natural armor)

monsterFluff.name: Anserath, the Honking Chaos
entries: Anserath, the Honking Chaos, is the demon lord of anger and pointless destruction. Originally created by {@creature Pazuzu|MaBJoV} as his war dog, Anserath immediately fell out of control and ran away from its master. After doing so, the Honking Chaos first joined {@creature Demogorgon|MTF}, then abandoned him too to go on its own way. Now Anserath nests in the Seeping Woods of Yeenoghu's Realm, claiming no allegiance to any demon other than itself and frequently scouring through the Abyss in search for an excuse to move battle to anybody or anything.

The demon lord is also known as the Raging Mouths because of its insatiable desire to bite and eat anything on its trail. The dozens of goose heads composing Anserath's body are perpetually honking in a mixture of anger and hunger, and will never lose the chance to try to "taste" something in front of them. As primordial chaos flows strongly inside of the demon lord, creatures bitten by it can experience severe avian mutations that can eventually turn the victim into an actual {@creature demogoose|Honkonomicon}, a demonic goosish horror.
See {@book Chapter 1|Honkonomicon|1|Anserath, the Honking Chaos} for more information about Anserath.

entries.name: Anserath's Lair
entries: Anserath has a permanent nest in the Seeping Woods, on the layer of the Abyss known as Yeenoghu's Realm. However, the Honking Chaos is often wreaking havonk somewhere else and has the habit to temporarily nest wherever it's spending some time. The Raging Mouth's lair is a tangle of materials picked from its surroundings, and extremely foul.

entries.name: Fowlish Mutations
entries: When Anserath feeds upon a creature, it randomly twists and warps the creature's body to make it more and more in the demon lord's resemblance, until it become a horrifying {@creature demogoose|Honkonomicon}*. When this happens, roll on the {@table Fowlish Mutations|Honkonomicon} table. The {@spell greater restoration} spell or similar magic heals a mutation, as does a {@spell remove curse} spell casted by a goose creature.

monsterFluff.name: Demogoose
entries: One of the noisiest and filthiest spawns of the Abyss, the demogoose is a fiend that exists as the result of Anserath's chaotic corruption on another life-form. Since even just the mere vicinity of the Honking Chaos is enough to make any hatching egg generate a demogoose, these fowlish horrors follow the demon lord's path and are considered an ominous sign of its influence over a region.

These fire breathing fiends are considered hateful and undesirable even by demon standards, since when a demogoose shakes its wings to fly, it releases all kinds of filth around itself. Also the demon adores to terrorize the enemies with its honk and then jump on them, taking advantage of the terror and mayhem that it just induced.

Demogeese incarnate primordial chaos to the point of making it impossible to restrain them. This, added to the fact that they know no fear, is particularly frustrating for cultists or even more powerful demons that wish to control them for their purpose. Whoever ends up summoning a demogoose (willingly or by mistake) soon realizes that they are better employed as a tool to wreck pure havoc, than as part of any careful planning.

items.name: Demogoose of Many Mouths
entries: Being an embodiment of raw chaos, demogeese are destined to be constantly warping and evolving (if you can call it so) even more than other members of demonkind. A demogoose that survives long enough and eats plenty of living creatures can eventually become a demogoose of many mouths: a stronger, bigger and more horrifying incarnation of Anserath's wrath and hunger, and closer to the demon lord's unnatural shape.

When a demogoose of many mouths arrives in an area where other minor members of its kind are present, all regular demogeese (and possibly some other evil goose creatures) can start to follow it, forming a flock that is gonna try to nest in the area. Then they will try to steal eggs from other creatures that, when kept in the nest for long enough, will spawn brand new demogeese. If not destroyed in time, these fiendish nests can soon go out of control and become a very big, honking concern for everyone in the region.

monsterFluff.name: Feathered Ooze
entries: This peculiar and particularly foul kind of ooze has adapted to live in places that are densely populated by geese or other avian creatures. The ooze adapted to look just like a pile of feathered waste, making it indistinguishable from the results of cleaning up a goose shed. A feathered ooze evolved to consider geese and similar creatures as a necessary part of its habitat, therefore doesn't usually attack them. In fact, it's not unknown for a farmer to be suddenly ambushed by one of these oozes while cleaning up a hen house.

The {@item Demonomicon of Iggwilv|TCE} claims that the first feathered ooze was generated after a battle between Anserath and Juiblex, as a result of the Honking Chaos feeding on the Faceless Lord's body and having an indigestion.

monsterFluff.name: Feathered Wrath
entries: Geese are renowned for getting angry fast. In certain cases,the anger of a goose can transcend life and death and transform it into an undead monster that is literally kept alive by its own bad intentions. This happens particularly often on geese that have been touched by the power of the demon lord Anserath, who can channel its rage through the bodies of other fellow geese so they can spread violence even beyond death.

When encountered, a feathered wrath will always attack on sight anything that moves. In fact, it is necessary for the monster to do so to stay alive, because being calm and reasonable can literally kill it. Even after being defeated, a feathered wrath can come back to life if there's still a battle inits vicinity, as it cannot resist the call for violence.

Feathered wraths love inflicting pain so much that they soon develop the habit to accumulate weapons and hide them within their feathers. Usually, a feathered wrath is encountered carrying about a half a dozen daggers, or any other weapon at the DM's choice.

images.credit: Polina Sokolova, edited by Simone Malvezzi

monsterFluff.name: Feathers Golem
entries: A feathers golem is an unusual implementation of the formula to create one of these artificial guardians. As opposed to other constructs that are made of more durable materials, a feathers golem is created when the crafter prefers adaptability to strength, or just has access to a great quantity of feathers (maybe because of the presence of other goose creatures). Its ability to pass through small cracks makes it ideal to guard places with particularly narrow corridors or natural caverns, and the capacity to attack with its feathers enables it to fight toe to toe with ranged opponents or even to control small groups of adversaries.
As it happens with other kinds of golems, this version can suffer from attacks of berserking rage, even aggravated by the presence of goose components as part of its body.

entries.name: Creation
entries: Crafting a feathers golem with a {@item manual of feathers golems|Honkonomicon|manual of golems created for this purpose} requires 20 days of work and 25,000 gp of supplies. See {@book Dungeon Master's Guide|DMG} for the complete rules on how to use a {@item manual of golems}.

monsterFluff.name: Flock of Geese
entries: When in a group, geese can become even more noisy and aggressive. In normal situations, a flock of geese is (mostly) harmless, but its behavior can become erratic when a stronger goose creature is established in the region.

monsterFluff.name: Giant Goose
entries: A bigger, scarier and angrier member of goosedom, the giant goose has the habit of charging whoever perceives as an enemy (basically, everyone) while honking in the most terrifying way. Because of their heavy body, giant geese are not as suited at flying as other oversized birds (like {@creature giant eagle||giant eagles} and {@creature giant owl||giant owls}), however they compensate with a much greater amount of anger.

images.title: Sir Goose on his faithful giant goose steed

monsterFluff.name: Goose
entries: Geese are territorial and social creatures: they are very protective of who belongs to their group, and they will honk very loudly at whoever they perceive as trespasser. This, paired with the fact that they don't behave particularly well with strangers, makes them great guard animals.
Domestic geese are usually the result of a kind of selective breeding that gives them a heavier body, at the expense of their fly efficiency.
Wild geese are more agile and, when in groups, fly in V-shaped formations.

monsterFluff.name: Goose of the Golden Feathers
entries: The fabled goose of the golden feathers (or golden goose) is a celestial child of the Great Golden Goose that exists with the purpose of helping the humbles and punishing the greedy ones. They can't speak, but will express themselves in very meaningful honks. Some temples of the Mother of Gold host a golden goose that is treated like a living saint and cared for with extreme care (some would say spoiled), as a form of respect for the goose's transcendent nature and in hope to maintain the goose's favor. Golden geese are usually pretty passive and lazy, even preferring to be carried around (as a form of respect for their divine nature, of course) other than flying or using their own legs. However, they won't hesitate to act if they witness cruelty, sparing none of their curses and beaks on whoever deserves them.

monsterFluff.name: Goose Skeleton
entries: Necromancers can turn geese into skeletons when they need a swimming undead that can chase off intruders or hunt down prey (or corpses) for them. Having no flesh, a goose skeleton lacks the ability to fly or honk (making it unusually silent for a goose) however their hollow bones make them particularly fast and agile. Since skeletons tend to repeat what they would be doing in life, goose skeletons have the unsettling habit to open their mouth into a silent honk, and can end up protecting the same territory or creature that they were attached to in life.

monsterFluff.name: Goose Zombie
entries: A goose zombie can rise when the corpse of a geese is infused with dark magic, purposely or by accident. Because of the goose's decomposing body, its honk will sound particularly hollow and distorted. Goose zombies are famous for trying to fly with their damaged wings that are often too decomposed to sustain them in the air.

monsterFluff.name: Gooseflayer Collective
entries: Mind flayers experimented on geese to turn them into waterborne scouts in service of their machiavellian plans.However the geese's chaotic nature, plus the stress from the constant telepathic honking, makes them particularly difficult to control for their illithid masters.

When a mind flayer colony makes the mistake of creating too many gooseflayers, these avian aberrations can rebel against their creators and form a peculiar form of psychically enhanced flock, called a gooseflayer collective. In this state, the bodies of all geese float by each other to form a perfect sphere with a single, fused mind that is, for all intended purposes, a whole creature in itself.

This is particularly threatening for a mind flayer colony, since the genius minds of the mutated geese can turn into a truly dangerous mastermind when fused together. For the stats of the individual gooseflayers and more information on them, see {@footnote Circle of the Honk|{@note #TODO BREW-869}} on the DMsGuild.

entries.name: One of Us
entries: The collective's objective is to rival an elder brain's power by becoming stronger (therefore ensuring that they can keep their freedom), so it needs to gather more and more geese to add to its cause (and to its spherical floating body). To achieve this, it will telepathically command all goose creatures in the area to find the collective and become one with it. The genius mind of the gooseflayers goes even beyond: in fact, why limit itself to "natural" geese? To ensure total assimilation, the aberration is able to mold the consciousness of any creature into the one of a goose, that they can then assimilate into the collective.

entries.name: A Gooseflayer Collective's Lair
entries: As opposed to its former masters, a gooseflayer collective doesn't suffer any aversion to sunlight. Therefore, it tends to choose the lair that is best for the collective's plans and objectives, possibly while staying out of reach of any illithid that might try to find the collective. The lair always includes a significant source of water, like a pond or a river, since it's important for the mental relief of the geese and, therefore, the well-being of the collective.

monsterFluff.name: Gray Honker
entries: A child of the Ur-goose inspired by the {@creature gray render|MPMM} (see {@book Monsters of the Multiverse|MPMM}), the gray honker embodies the most protective (and awkward) aspects of its landborn relative. While this monstrosity can be extremely dangerous and violent, it acts the most ferocious when in need to protect whoever considers "its flock", to the point of using its own body and wings as a living shield.

This avian giant can also perform its own peculiar version of the "dance" of the gray honker: a furious whirlwind of claw slashes, screeches and deafening honks made with the purpose of confounding the surrounding enemies.

monsterFluff.name: Great Golden Goose
entries: The timeless Great Golden Goose is widely considered the godmother of all goosekind and a symbol of freedom,prosperity and transcending enlightenment. While the Mother of Gold is a being of light and virtue, she's not to be mistaken as a passive entity, as both her and her children (the celestial {@creature goose of the golden feathers|Honkonomicon|geese of the golden feathers}) are famous for bestowing curses on whoever might deserve them.

An easy way to anger the Great Golden Goose is to abuse the gift delivered by her, act with excessive greed or hurt her "flock" or sacred temples. At the same time, she also embodies some of the most temperamental aspects of goosedom, making it easy to trigger her anger even with minor infractions. It is not unknown for a high rank cultist of the Great Golden Goose to go on a quest to find its patron, in the purpose to appease her rage (or at least understand the reason for it) after mysterious curses are being laid for apparently no reason.
See {@book Chapter 1|Honkonomicon|1} for more information about the lore, cults and powers of the Great Golden Goose.

entries.name: The Age-old Question
entries: Who came first, the egg or the goose? Not even the wisest sages know the answer. As much as nobody understands when and where the Great Golden Goose came to be, also none can say if she will ever find her end. When (and if) the Great Golden Goose dies or is destroyed, it comes back to life after one year and one day, hatching from one of the several golden eggs that exist in the world. For the first eighty-eight days of her life, she's indistinguishable from a {@creature goose of the golden feathers|Honkonomicon}* and has its same statistics. Then, suddenly, it will evolve into her final, divine incarnation of avian glory once more, while rewarding or punishing whoever treated her particularly kindly or cruelly in the meanwhile.
The only ways to stop the rejuvenation of the Great Golden Goose is to rid the multiverse of any golden egg (an almost impossible task) or to prevent her spirit from traveling freely after death.

entries.name: The Great Golden Gooses's Lair
entries: The Great Golden Goose follows a perpetual migration that begins in the Feywild, travels through each of the good-aligned planes (Ysgard, Arborea, the Beastlands, Elysium, Bytopia and Mount Celestia) and ends in in the Astral Sea. The migration is a metaphorical journey from passion to asceticism, starting in the planes that are more connected to strong emotions, and finishing in the ones that embody elevation and transcendence. The Goose has a nest in each of these planes, always in a location that's particularly remote and dangerous to reach.

images.title: A holy symbol of the Great Golden Goose

monsterFluff.name: Grifoose
entries: When the Ur-goose saw the mighty {@creature griffon}, it decided to tryout the same formula (with a personal twist, obviously) and created the grifoose. This goose-headed monstrosity has the same frightless spirit of the original, but pushed to the extreme of stupidity. In fact, a grifoose doesn't fear anything, even when it should.

Willingly or not, the Ur-goose managed to play a joke on every future creature that wished to ride its children, since the innate stubbornness of this monstrosity makes it extremely difficult to train and control it. More than once, a proud knight of the sky approaches a grifoose mistaking it for its more noble version, just to be thrown out of its saddle shortly after. However, a rider that learns how to deal with such a difficult mount, will be rewarded with a companion that doesn't run away even in front of the mightiest of dragons.

monsterFluff.name: Honkatrice
entries: Similar to a {@creature cockatrice} in many ways, a honkatrice is something between a lizard, a bat and a goose. These flying monstrosities share the same transformative powers of their similars, but with a twist: instead of turning creatures to stone, the bite of the honkatrice turns the victim into a honkatrice itself. This, added with the fact that these creatures act stronger when in groups, makes them particularly dangerous: one honkatrice can be enough to transform a whole village or more into a huge skein of these insidious honkers.

monsterFluff.name: Honkdra of the Ponds
entries: When the Ur-goose designed its avian creations, the honkdra was the concept on which the Primordial of Havonk experimented the most, giving birth to several variants of this multiheaded monstrosity. Aside from any variation, a honkdra is always a mockery of the infamous hydra, known to test the mettle of several great champions. The so called "honkdra of the ponds" is one of the smallest and weaker of its kind (and that's saying something), physically less threatening than a regular {@creature hydra} but with the habit of swallowing anything that moves, and a terrible attitude.

Inspired by the spawns of the blood of the dragon god Lernaea, slain by Tiamat at the dawn of time, the Ur-goose proceeded to craft a creature even more hateful and insidious, gifting to its children a kind of magical plumage that is even impervious to spells. Because of this, it can be particularly complicated for the adventurers to use fire to cauterize the cut heads of the honkdra, since they can't rely on fire cantrips.
For more versions of this creature, see {@footnote Honkdra|{@note #TODO BREW-871}} from Lord of Eat on DMsGuild.

monsterFluff.name: Honkecho
entries: When a group of geese that was particularly numerous (or angry) dies, it can leave behind a honkecho: the undead remains of their fowlish screams, resounding for eternity. This collective is made of pure sounds, as it is literally the honking of dozens of geese that constantly repeats itself, forever. The noise that comes from an honkecho is enough to confuse or drive most people crazy, and can shatter both matter and mind.

A honkecho is definitely noticeable through hearing, but {@condition invisible}. Only when it manifests its violent honks, it briefly becomes visible as a flash of spirits that resemble waves of sound.

monsterFluff.name: Honkimera
entries: Back in the days when Anserath was Demogorgon's pet and companion, the Prince of Demons gave birth to the {@creature chimera} to make up for the "lack of creativity" that he witnessed on the Prime Material. Following the lead of its master, the Honking Chaos decided to give birth to its own version of this monstrosity and created the honkimera: a hybrid between a goose, a cow and a green dragon (chosen because of the fixation that Anserath has with poisonous gasses).

Falling victim of the draconic component of its nature, a honkimera desires to hoard a treasure, but is not smart enough to understand the difference between valuables and garbage. Because of this, a honkimera's nest will be cluttered with anything: precious gems, household items, entire wagons (full or empty), broken or rotten goods, and more.

monsterFluff.name: Honkraken
entries: A honkraken is a creature from the dawn of time and a peak specimen of goosedom. In the age when the war between gods and primordials was raging, the former created the {@creature kraken||krakens} as their soldiers, while the mischievous Ur-goose gave birth to the honkrakens as a way to openly mock them. The Primordial of Havonk infused its children with the echo of its ancestral honk, and gifted them its magical plumage that protects them from heat, cold and even magic.

Even if significantly weaker than their tentacled counterparts, the honkrakens are still terrifying creatures that can (and will) spread chaos, fear and wreck with great ease. Their talent for senseless destruction is so great, that they attracted the attention (and admiration) of Anserath, the Honking Chaos itself, that gifted them with magical powers aimed at delivering even more havoc.

Nowadays, honkrakens are considered no more than a legend, or a tale from drunken sailors that nobody can (or want to) believe. However, when a storm is brewing in the open sea and the thunder in the sky mixes with an echoing honk from the depths, many start to reconsider these legends. When they do, often, it's already too late.

entries.name: A Honkraken's Lair
entries: A honkraken usually lives in a deep, narrow trench, in an underwater cave or under the surface of a sargasso island.There, they collect amounts of items that range between the legendary and the completely useless, as their avian mind doesn't comprehend the difference between treasure and trash.

images.title: An ambitious warlock of the Honking Chaos summons the power of the Honkonomicon to bind a honkraken while wielding the cane of the silly goose. His vicious goose familiar assists him in this dangerous endeavor.

monsterFluff.name: Megoosa
entries: Closely related with {@creature medusa||medusas} in terms of origin and nature, a megoosa is what happened to someone that tempered with the power of geese and somehow failed. This could be the result of a curse from the Great Golden Goose, a bad deal with Anserath or even just a mood swing from the Ur-goose. Whatever the cause, the creature's desire to manipulate the power of geese turned against it, partially transforming it into what it wanted to control. Now the megoosa tries to share this curse with whoever comes by, as it aims to turn other people into geese just as medusas would turn them into stone.

While medusas are susceptible to their own gaze reflected into mirrors, megoosas are affected by the power of the honks of geese, which can trigger a new transformation into them until they finally turn into a complete goose.
In combat, megoosas usually hold a {@item greatclub|PHB} in a pretty upset way, and can throw quills magically enhanced by chaos magic that they pick from their heads.

monsterFluff.name: Mother Goose
entries: Famous for her nursery rhymes and beloved children stories, Mother Goose is considered by many no more than a fictional character from the cover of a book of bedtime stories. However, who is acquainted with the powers of geese knows the truth: that Mother Goose is more than real. This apparently harmless granny is actually a being from the feywild that embodies some of the most protective aspects of goosedom. Her words and tales carry great magic, and they have the power to deliver teaching stories that can deeply affect who listens, or even to bring stories to life.

Mother Goose is the most sweet and comprehensive with children and good hearted beings in general, but has no hesitation to punish evildoers by hitting them with her walking cane. Every hit by her cane feels like a punishment and strikes the body as much as the morale.

items.name: Primal Honkecho
entries: Honkechoes exist since the dawn of time. In the age of the war between primordial and deities, the Ur-goose was screaming to bring destruction to its enemies or to grief the defeat of a dear member of its flock. The most intense and meaningful of these honks carried with them enough emotion and willpower to come into existence as their own creature, becoming the undying message that the Ur-goose left to the world.

monsterFluff.name: Rhonk
entries: If you hear thunder, there's a storm coming. However, if you hear a thunder that sounds like pure fowlish destruction, that's a rhonk. These titanic birds have a wingspan of almost two hundred feet, and are usually kept as pets by the most powerful giants. A rhonk that escapes its master can bring down havoc on entire kingdoms before being stopped by somebody strong (and crazy) enough to face them, its master comes to reclaim it or (more likely) the avian terror just loses interest and goes somewhere else.

Rhonks are the more clumsy, destructive and erratic cousins of {@creature roc||rocs}. Back in the days when Annam, father of all giants, created the rocs as a mean to try to level the field in the war between his children and the dragons, his vassal Memnor tried a similar effort. While Annam created a noble, reliable mount for his children, Memnor the trickster manipulated the chaotic energies of the Ur-goose to create the rhonk and gifted. Since that day, rhonks have become a favorite pet for cloud giants in particular, that consider them like a giant joke.

images.title: An adventurer flying on the wings of a rhonk

monsterFluff.name: Ur-goose
entries: The Ur-goose, also known as the Primordial Havonk, is an ancestral being who embodies natural chaos in its raw state, considered to be the first goose that ever walked on earth (even if the timeless {@creature Great Golden Goose|Honkonomicon} might have preceded it) and gave birth to several exemplars of goosekind. The Ur-goose's body is a towering 40-foot tall mass of raw elements that are perpetually swirling, shifting and mixing with each other, as they can never find a stable form. At the core of the Ur-goose lies a brilliant nebula, which is the source of its creative power.

Despite its immense size, the titan's shifting body is capable of concealing itself with great ease, usually by mixing with the elemental matter of its surrounding environment. In fact, the Primordial Havonk is renowned to be one the most clever tricksters and escapists of the multiverse. After defeating the primordials at the dawn of time, the gods have been hunting for the Ur-goose incessantly for eons, with no success. In fact, the Primordial Havonk takes great joy into seeing the frustration of other beings going on a wild goose chase to find it or catch it, often with poor or no results.

Even if the Ur-goose is often running away or hiding, there are times when it might decide to take a stance and fight back, or even to actively move war to its enemies. This is usually the case when civilization is trying to impose its "order" on an untainted natural area, or when something poses a great danger to goosekind as whole. When the Ur-goose is fighting the rules of matter, magic and reality constantly bend around its chaotic essence, while its honk has the wildest effects (both harmful and beneficial) to its enemies.
For more information on the lore, cults and powers of the Ur-goose, see {@book Chapter 1|Honkonomicon|1|Ur-goose, Primordial of Havonk}.

entries.name: Ur-goose's Lair
entries: Typically, the Ur-goose frequents the natural areas of the Prime Material that are the most far away from civilization. The Primordial Havonk changes location often to always be one step ahead of its chasers, but when it chooses a lair, it is often an untainted natural area with dense environmental features (like a tangled jungle or a complex of narrow caves) with plenty of spots to hide.

images.title: The Ur-goose in one of its many, threatening forms

monsterFluff.name: Weregoose
entries: A weregoose is an absolute agent of chaos. As humanoids, they develop longer necks, smaller eyes and thicker lips. In their humanoid forms, they prefer weapons that enable them to create the most mayhem in the shortest amount of time, like {@item greatclub|PHB|greatclubs} and {@item flail|PHB|flails}, but they are clever enough to change to a more suitable weapon if they need more finesse.
Weregeese infect other humanoids out of spite, to punish someone that misbehaved or just to create more chaos.Sometimes, they might infect somebody that they really wish to protect.
When they can, weregeese gather in very tight communities, developing strong interpersonal bonds and a great desire to protect the weakest members.
More {@variantrule Player Characters as Lycanthropes|MM|information on lycanthropes} can be found in the {@book Monster Manual|MM} .

legendaryGroup.name: Anserath, the Honking Chaos
lairActions: On initiative count 20 (losing initiative ties), Anserath can take one of the following lair actions; it can't take the same lair action two rounds in a row:

items.name: Festering Filth
entries: Until the next initiative count 20, creatures in the lair have disadvantage on saving throws against poison and take an extra 5 ({@damage 1d10}) poison damage whenever they take any damage from any source.

items.name: Unbearable Noise
entries: All of the demon lord's heads bicker and honk purposelessly. Until the next initiative count 20, all creatures in the lair except for Anserath are {@condition deafened}, have vulnerability to psychic damage and make Wisdom saving throws with disadvantage.

items.name: Warping Goose Heads
entries: Three demonic goose heads spawn from the ground and beak as many nearby creatures. Each target makes a {@dc 24} Dexterity saving throw, taking 10 ({@damage 3d6}) magical piercing damage and becoming {@condition grappled} on a failed save ({@dc 18} to escape). A creature {@condition grappled} by one of these heads is eligible to be targeted by the Feed the Geese legendary action. The heads disappear when Anserath uses another lair action, freeing any creature {@condition grappled} by them.

regionalEffects: The region containing Anserath's nest is warped by its magic,creating one or more of the following effects:

items.name: Corrupted Birth
entries: Once per day, an egg hatching within 6 miles of the lair gives birth to a {@creature demogoose|Honkonomicon}* if Anserath wishes so. The {@creature demogoose|Honkonomicon} grows to full size within one round.

items.name: Raging Geese
entries: Goose creatures within 6 miles of the lair develop violent tendencies (even more than usual) and could try to eat any other creature.

items.name: Filthy and Hungry
entries: Within 6 miles of the lair, creatures need two days of food per day to sustain themselves.Additionally, Wisdom ({@skill Medicine}) checks have disadvantage, and Charisma ({@skill Intimidation}) checks have advantage.

regionalEffects: If Anserath dies, these effects fade over the course of {@dice 1d10} days.

legendaryGroup.name: Gooseflayer Collective
lairActions: On initiative count 20 (losing initiative ties), the collective can take one of the following lair actions; it can't take the same lair action two rounds in a row:

items.name: Honking Barrier
entries: The collective casts a {@spell wall of fire} spell ({@dc 18}) that deals thunder damage instead.

items.name: Honking Pulse
entries: All creatures within 120 feet of the collective that are currently maintaining {@status concentration} on a spell take 5 ({@damage 1d10}) psychic damage and have disadvantage on the next {@status concentration} check.

items.name: Flock Intrusion
entries: Three creatures that the collective can see make a {@dc 18} Intelligence saving throw. On a failed save, a target becomes {@condition charmed} by the collective. A target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

regionalEffects: The region containing the collective's lair is influenced by its psionic energies, creating one or more of the following effects:

items.name: Goose Vision
entries: The collective can cast {@spell scrying} at will on any goose creature it can detect with its Goose Sense.

items.name: Goose Whispers
entries: The collective casts {@spell suggestion} ({@dc 18}, not limited to humanoid targets) on a goose creature that it can perceive through its Goose Sense and that is having a long rest or that is {@condition incapacitated}. It delivers the suggested command telepathically. If the goose creature succeeds on the saving throw, it becomes immune to this regional effect (but can still be targeted by the {@spell suggestion} spell of the collective in other circumstances).

items.name: Honkanoia
entries: Creatures within 5 miles of a collective feel like they are hearing a honk, even when there's no goose in the area.

regionalEffects: If the collective dies, these effects immediately end.

legendaryGroup.name: Great Golden Goose
lairActions: On initiative count 20 (losing initiative ties), the Great Golden Goose can take one of the following lair actions; the Goose can't take the same lair action two rounds in a row:

items.name: Cloud of Golden Feathers
entries: The Goose creates a cloud of golden feathers in a 20-foot radius from a point she can see. The cloud blocks line of sight, and any non-celestial creature in the area is {@condition blinded}. The spell lasts until another lair action is used, up to 1 hour.

items.name: Starry Sparkles
entries: The Goose casts the {@spell faerie fire} spell ({@dc 25}) using only verbal components and without the need to maintain {@status concentration}. The spell lasts until another lair action is used, up to 1 minute.

items.name: Stupefying Enlightenment
entries: A random creature in the lair receives prophetic vision. The target makes a {@dc 20} Wisdom saving throw, that it can choose to fail. On a failed save, it receives the benefits of the {@spell augury} or {@spell communion} spell (one question only) but is {@condition incapacitated} until the end of its next turn.

regionalEffects: The territory within 5 miles of the Great Golden Goose is altered by her superior goosish influence, which creates one or more of the following effects:

items.name: Golden Migration
entries: Goose creatures are attracted to the area within 5 miles of the Great Golden Goose and, once they are there, feel a reflection of her emotional state. This might or not influence the course of action of the creatures.

items.name: Honklightenment
entries: Anybody can interact with goose creatures within 5 miles of the Great Golden Goose as if they casted the {@spell speak with animal} spell.

items.name: Luck of Gold
entries: Creatures within 5 miles of the Goose that make an Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) or Wisdom ({@skill Survival}) check, always find precious goods or coins valuable at least {@dice 2d20} gp, or more (DM's choice). Once a creature benefits from this, it won't benefit again until the next dawn. Creatures that abuse the Luck of Gold might incur into a curse.

regionalEffects: If the Goose dies, these effects end on {@dice 1d10} days.

legendaryGroup.name: Honkraken
lairActions: On initiative count 20 (losing initiative ties), a honkraken can take one of the following lair actions; the honkraken can't take the same lair action two rounds in a row:

items.name: Goose Alpha
entries: {@dice 1d3} creatures with the Goose tag that the honkraken can see can use their reaction to move at half speed, make an attack, or both.

items.name: Honking Confusion
entries: The {@homebrew Honkraken|[MON]} casts the {@spell confusion} spell ({@dc 18}) with only verbal component and without the need to maintain {@status concentration}. A creature that fails the saving throw is also {@condition deafened}. The spell lasts until another lair action is used, up to 1 minute.

items.name: Shonkwave
entries: Each creature within 60 feet of the honkraken makes a {@dc 22} Strength saving throw, falling {@condition prone} and being pushed 20 feet away on failure. If the target is thrown into a solid object or another creature, they both must succeed on a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw or take {@damage 1d6} bludgeoning damage for every 10 feet the target was thrown, and be knocked {@condition prone}.

regionalEffects: The territory within 5 miles of a honkraken is altered by the creature's chaotic presence, which creates one or more of the following effects:

items.name: Fowlish Sightings
entries: Creatures within 5 miles of a honkraken believe that they are seeing a goose under most surfaces of water.

items.name: Goose Uprising
entries: Creatures with the Goose tag within 5 miles of a honkraken start to behave in a (even) more chaotic and violent way than usual. Regular geese start to gather as one or more {@creature flock of geese|Honkonomicon|flocks of geese}* and might attack other creatures on sight.

items.name: Storming Mood
entries: The honkraken alters the weather (always for the worse) as per the {@spell control weather} spell.

regionalEffects: If the honkraken dies, these effects immediately end.

legendaryGroup.name: Ur-goose
lairActions: On initiative count 20 (losing initiative ties), the Ur-goose can take one of the following lair actions; it can't take the same lair action two rounds in a row:

items.name: Honkemental Nebula
entries: The Ur-goose casts the {@spell fog cloud} spell with only verbal component, originating from a point within its lair. Each creature that begins its turn inside the cloud takes 5 ({@damage 1d10}) damage of a random type from its Honkemental Honktropy (see statblock). If the Ur-goose uses another lair action, the spell ends.

items.name: Reverse Gravity
entries: The Ur-goose casts the {@spell reverse gravity} spell ({@dc 25}) with only verbal component. This spell doesn't require {@status concentration}, but lasts only until the next initiative count 20.

items.name: Wild Magic
entries: A random {@table Wild Magic Surge|PHB|wild magic effect} (see table in the {@book Player's Handbook|PHB}) triggers on a random creature that is within the lair.

regionalEffects: The region containing the Ur-gooses's lair is warped by its chaotic essence, creating one or more of the following effects:

items.name: Crumble Civilization
entries: Artificial structures within 5 miles of the lair take 2 ({@damage 1d4}) force damage every 24 hours, being separated back into raw elements.

items.name: Divination Screen
entries: Casting a divination spell while within 5 miles of the lair or on a target within that area requires a successful {@dc 25} Intelligence ({@skill Arcana}) check.

items.name: Make Geese Wild
entries: Goose creatures within 5 miles of the lair become more evasive, more violent, or both.

regionalEffects: If the Ur-goose dies, these effects instantly fade.

variantrule.name: Player Characters as Weregeese
entries: A character that becomes a weregoose gains a Constitution of 12 and a Dexterity of 14 if the score isn't already higher. Attack and damage rolls for the beak are based on whichever is higher of the character's Strength and Dexterity. For the Honk action, the DC is 8 + the character's proficiency bonus + Charisma or Constitution modifier (character's choice). For more information on {@variantrule Player Characters as Lycanthropes|MM|lycanthropes as player characters}, see the {@book Monster Manual|MM}.

table.name: Fowlish Mutations
rows: The target's feet become webbed. Its speed is halved, but gains a swim speed equal to its basic speed.

The target's head becomes the one of a goose. It can't speak or cast spells with verbal components, but can make unarmed attacks with the beak that deal {@damage 1d4} damage plus its Strength modifier
The target's arms become goose wings. The target drops everything that it's holding and has no hands anymore, but gains a flying speed of 15 feet.
The target grows oversized feathers all over its body. It has disadvantage on Dexterity checks (including initiative) but makes all saving throws against cold with advantage.

The target grows a set of hardened bone spurs on each of its elbows or wrists. These bone spurs can be used as unarmed attacks, and deal {@damage 1d6} bludgeoning damage plus its Strength modifier on a hit.
The target's neck becomes surprisingly long and can't sustain the head's weight anymore. The target has disadvantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks.

The target's tongue develops oversized razor-sharp teeth. Whenever the target takes an action that requires it to swallow or speak (like drinking a potion or casting a spell with verbal components) roll a {@dice d20}. On a 1, the target takes {@damage 1} piercing damage.

The target's brain shrinks and becomes a goose brain. The target has advantage on saving throws against being {@condition frightened} and disadvantage on Intelligence attack rolls, ability checks and saving throws.

entries: Old Mother Goose,
When she wanted to wander,
Would ride through the air
On a very fine gander.
Humpty Dumpty
Sat on a Wall
Humpty Dumpty
Had a Great Fall
All the King's Horses
And All the King's Men
Couldn't Put Humpty
Together Again
Old King Cole was a merry old soul,
And a merry old soul was he;
He called for his pipe, and he called for his bowl,
And he called for his fiddlers three.
Every fiddler he had a fiddle,
And a very fine fiddle had he;
Oh there's none so rare, as can compare,
With King Cole and his fiddlers three.
Ring-a-round the rosie,
A pocket full of posies,
Ashes! Ashes!
We all fall down.
Cows in the meadows
Eating buttercups
A-tishoo! A-tishoo!
We all jump up.
Little Jack Horner
Sat in the corner,
Eating his Christmas pie;
He put in his thumb,
And pulled out a plum,
And said, "What a good boy am I!"
Wee Willie Winkie runs through the town,
Upstairs and downstairs in his night-gown,
Tapping at the window, crying at the lock,
Are the children in their bed, for it's past ten o'clock?
Baa, baa, black sheep,
Have you any wool?
Yes, sir, yes, sir,
Three bags full;
One for the master,
And one for the dame,
And one for the little boy
Who lives down the lane.
Star light, star bright,
First star I see tonight,
I wish I may, I wish I might,
Have this wish I wish tonight.
